topics.DESCRIPTION: Statistics on the number of state and local government civilian employees and their gross payrolls for the month of March.
Government finances include revenues, expenditures (spending), debt, and assets (cash and security holdings).
Government finances include revenues, expenditures (spending), debt, and assets (cash and security holdings).
Government finances include revenues, expenditures (spending), debt, and assets (cash and security holdings).
Education finance data include revenues, expenditures, debt, and assets [cash and security holdings] of elementary and secondary public school systems.
Public pension systems provide revenues, expenditures, financial assets, and membership information for state and local government defined benefit retirement systems.
State and local government tax collections by major tax category including property, income, and sales taxes.
The Census Bureau provides state legislatures with the small area census population tabulations necessary for legislative redistricting.
Information about the nation s workforce, changes in employment rates and unemployment rates at the national, state, county or city level.
Work experience includes data on employment patterns, work history, hours worked, and employment duration.
Data on the usual number of hours worked per week and weeks worked per year by employed persons.
Classification of workers by whether they work part-time (less than 35 hours per week) or full-time (35 hours or more per week).
Classification of employment by job tenure characteristics, distinguishing temporary from permanent positions.
Data on workers' employment duration, job changes, and career progression over time.
The Census Bureau collects data on occupation for Americans in the labor force across several surveys.
The Census Bureau collects data on industry across several surveys.
The Census Bureau collects data on class of worker for Americans in the labor force across several surveys.
Commuting including means of transportation, time of departure, mean travel time to work, vehicles available, distance traveled, and expenses.
Work from home refers to a worker s usage of the home as a workplace.
Housing units are defined as a house, apartment, mobile home, or group of rooms occupied or intended as separate living quarters with direct access from the outside or a common hall.
Measuring how quickly new multifamily rental and condo/co-op units (5+ units/building) are rented or sold after completion.
The proportion of households that are occupied by the owners, measured as the percentage of owner-occupied housing units.
Data on housing units that are not occupied, including their characteristics and reasons for vacancy.
The percentage of housing units that are vacant, calculated separately for rental and homeowner inventory.
Detailed information about vacant housing units including duration of vacancy, condition, and intended use.
Economic aspects of housing including costs, values, mortgages, taxes, and insurance.
The estimated market value of owner-occupied housing units and the price paid for home purchases.
Costs for homeowner or renter insurance, utility services (electricity, gas, water, sewer), and other housing-related fees.
Expenditures on renovations, repairs, and improvements to housing units.
Annual property taxes assessed on housing units and land.
Monthly mortgage payments including principal, interest, and related financing costs.
Monthly gross rent including contract rent and estimated utilities and fuels.
Data on late housing payments, mortgage foreclosures, and rental evictions.
Federal, state, or local housing assistance programs and tax benefits for homeowners or renters.
Characteristics of landlords and entities that own rental housing properties.
Characteristics of occupied housing units including household composition and living arrangements.
Demographic and socioeconomic characteristics of household members in occupied housing units.
The number of persons per room in occupied housing units, used as a measure of crowding.
The amount of living space available per person in a housing unit.
Vehicles available to households and transportation access from housing units.
Structural and amenity features of housing units.
The year construction was completed on the housing structure.
The size of the land parcel on which a housing structure sits.
The total floor area of a housing unit measured in square feet.
The number of housing units and floors in a building or structure.
The number and types of rooms in a housing unit, such as bedrooms, bathrooms, and kitchens.
Equipment and fuel types used for heating and cooling housing units.
Water source, sewage disposal, and plumbing fixtures available in housing units.
Availability of telecommunications and internet services in housing units.
Parking facilities and garage space available with housing units.
Exterior amenities such as yards, porches, decks, and outdoor structures.
Construction materials and structural elements of housing units including walls, roofs, and foundations.
Characteristics of the surrounding area including access to services and community amenities.
Conditions affecting health, safety, and accessibility of housing units.
Features that accommodate persons with disabilities, such as ramps, grab bars, and accessible bathrooms.
Housing features related to emergency response and disaster readiness.
Housing quality issues including structural problems, water leaks, and pest infestations.
Characteristics of the person (householder) who owns or rents the housing unit.
Whether a housing unit is owner-occupied or renter-occupied.
Demographic and economic characteristics of householders including age, race, and income.
Homeowners who have never previously owned a home.
The year the current householder began occupying the housing unit.
Previous residence and moving patterns of householders.
Data on both newly constructed and existing housing inventory.
Net change in housing units from year to year, including new construction, demolitions, and conversions.
Statistics on newly built housing units including building permits, starts, completions, and sales.
Factory-built housing units that are transportable in one or more sections.
Housing units in multi-unit structures where owners hold title to individual units (condos) or shares in a corporation (co-ops).
Money income from all sources including earnings, investments, and transfer payments.
Total income received by households, families, and individuals before taxes.
Income from wages, salaries, and self-employment for individuals.
Public assistance payments and social insurance benefits such as Social Security and unemployment compensation.
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits for purchasing food.
Measures of income distribution such as Gini coefficients and income ratios.
Data measuring economic hardship based on income thresholds.
Federal poverty thresholds based on pre-tax cash income compared to family size and composition.
Alternative poverty measure that accounts for taxes, work expenses, and non-cash benefits.
Broader measures of economic security and material hardship beyond income poverty.
Net worth including owned assets minus debts, such as home equity, savings, and investments.
The number of jobs gained and lost through business expansions, contractions, births, and deaths.
Product inventories, including raw materials, partially finished products, and more.
The total value of raw materials, work-in-process goods, and finished products held by businesses.
Business inventories classified by accounting method (FIFO, LIFO, or other valuation approaches).
Inventories valued using the Last-In, First-Out accounting method.
Measures of business formation, growth, contraction, and closure over time.

Federal, state and local government data as well as voting, redistricting, apportionment and congressional affairs.

Data covering people and business relating to health in America.

Racial data collected in accordance with guidelines provided by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB), and these data are based on self-identification.
